pros: Excellent benefits / prices for benefits ; in my location, there was room to advance - saw many people promoted from within; the underwriting software had some positive attributes in that it did a great job of dropping correct automated conditions with less editing than I do in Encompass ; pay was fair ; ability to work remotely a few days a week; regularly held underwriting meetings to keep abreast of policy changes. Decent PTO and holidays. Management generally let's you work flex time - I am not a morning person and generally didn't get to work before 9am. My manager never gave me a hard time about it as long as I got 40 hours in. Bonus was about 10% of my base as long as quality was good. Also I felt that quality control was generally pretty fair in their reviews, although others disagree with me on that. Overall I was appreciative to have this job.
cons: Not able to get your DE unless you worked in a particular physical office in 2 states only; lots of regulation impact on employees - such as, not allowed to use excel (seriously, and if you were caught using excel worksheets you were in trouble), random mid-year in-person interviews by internal auditors; training was rough - not enough access to help when needed and the corporate trainor didn't even know how to use the lending software - sent us back totally unprepared ; they use a program called "core" for underwriting and it is glitchy (for example, when the last condition is cleared the loan will automatically CTC itself. So let's say you cleared all uw conditions, but the title and appraisal were not in file yet. Those come in later and get cleared by the collateral review team. Without any warning, your loan issues it's own clear to close status. This causes you to miss anything new added to the loan before the loan gets audited by QC. Also, once a loan is in CTC status it can never be moved back. So if the loan suddenly isn't ctc anymore (let's say documents expired), it will stay in CTC status, making it hard to manage your pipeline/be aware of the true status of a loan.  Also- the system "recommends" a document to be attached to a condition and people overseas will attach conditions at 2am. (Processors don't really process here, they just resubmit loans when they see that the system recommended a document to a condition). No control at all over what processors do. Underwriter essentially becomes the processor much of the time. Finally, exceptions to credit policy were painstaking to request. Long turn time to get a reply and the system would lock you from making any changes, including canceling the request! This was very annoying.

review_title: Wells Fargo's competitive advantage are their employees
pros: I have worked for Wells Fargo for almost two years. I started as a teller and moved to a lead teller position. Wells has an extensive and great training program. They invest in their employees. In my district, I see my district manager every week and it feels less like a huge corporate company and more like extended family. Wells has great benefits and great incentive plans. Sales goals have consistently been lowered every year. Wells is focusing more on ethics and customer service than sales. You can get promoted in less than a year, like I did, if you work hard, take the initiative and ask for help you will succeed. Sales are extremely easy to achieve. Customer service is wells number one priority. You need to be customer orientated. The branch is extremely fun and high energy makes people excited to come to work. In comparison to Chase or BOA, Wells is the way to go. They invest more time and money into their employees and care about their development.
cons: Hours are tough. Working 9-6 or like my branch,10-7 can be very tough. Not having a set schedule or working at a Sunday open branch is also difficult. Most branches are going to be transitioning soon to sunday open branches. The pilot program is going well and bringing in an increase in profit. Customer's can be entitled jerks.

review_title: Avoid if you are an experienced professional.
pros:
Good salary structure.
Good benefits.
Good for freshers.
cons:
The problem is with US management. Here almost every team works with US team that is why timings are kept 1:30-10:30. They will not tell you about timings during interview and offer. They told me after I accepted offer and out of my curiosity I asked about it when I received a shift declaration form during onboarding. Do not be befooled by all the positive reviews above because Wells fargo has recently had a change in technical leadership and it is for the worst. The cons I have listed below have started in almost all teams in my BU and suddenly you can see lot of resignations in the organisation in India.

1.) The US managers (who are mostly Indians) treat you like slaves. There is no end time for you to log off. It might extend till 3-4 in the morning.

2.) The US managers are not open to discussions. One reason is they are purely non technical guys who worked as traders in the bank.

3.) Too much micromanagement from US leads and especially manager.

4.) Agile is just for the sake of it and is hardly followed. No one cares about story points, acceptance criteria etc.

5.) No retrospective meetings.  No sprint planning meetings.

6.) Deadlines are decided by manager and NOT by developers who will be working on it. They ALWAYS have crunch timelines and you will be questioned for task completion  from the next day of starting the task.

7.) Hardly any focus on quality of work because there is always a strict timeline and most of the US developers are contractors. Their projects are of 1-1.5 year duration so people focus on delivering quickly compromising quality because of fear of escalations.

8.) If you raise technical issues, roadblocks and ask for extra time for task completion, the US managers threaten you to be escalated with your India manager as well as US top management. 

This company has one of the worst work cultures I have had compared to all 5 companies I have worked with. Please join if you do not have any other offer.

job_title: ICC Investment Resource Consultant I in Charlotte, NC
pros: 401k vesting schedule is immediate, no cliff or graded vesting schedule which is nice because then you can take your 401k match money and run. PTO package is decent too.
cons:
I went through the licensing program through associate staffing. You get 1 shot at passing the SIE industry essentials, Series 7 & 66. Luckily for me I was able to pass them, if you fail any of these tests you will be let go from your contract. Once passing all the tests you will be interviewed for the role. The job is pretty much guaranteed at this point since they spent the money getting you licensed for the role. As most of you know already, these particular licenses enable you to provide financial advice regarding investments such as Mutual Funds. However, in this specific role you’re unable to give any advice. There are 3 products you get to discuss with customers which would be a Wells Trade Account, Intuitive investor, or offering a phone based or full service FA. The customer has to decide which of these options is best for them. As the licensed associate you’re not able to tell them what would be best, oftentimes this creates an awkward experience between you and the customer because they’re looking at you to be the expert and know what would be best suited for them. The role is basic and becomes mundane fast. 

Expect to be taking back to back calls for your entire shift. 
Expect to repeat disclosures on every call. 
Expect your calls to be reviewed constantly and brought to your attention if you failed to state verbatim one of the 5+ disclosures. 
Expect to work Saturdays if you’re new. 
Expect to be in the role for a very long time, I was in the role for 2 years. I was constantly looking to get into an analytical role. Despite being in the role 2 years I was unable to interview for any other position I applied for internally. As for my colleagues they experienced the same problems regarding internal promotions. 
Expect your manager to miss all your 1 on 1 meetings. 
Expect to be a number and a droid. 
Expect upset customers, as most customers resent WFA for the scandals and disorganized client services group. 
Expect to regret the job you have chosen. 

On the final note I wanted to share the moment I was working Saturday in March 2020, when the COVID pandemic was on the rise and a stay at home order was issued by the NC governor. During work on Saturday a gentlemen in a hazmat suit showed up at my desk, informing me they would be spraying because someone in a nearby cubicle had been quarantined for being in close contact with someone who had COVID. My colleague and I, who were the only 2 scheduled at the Charlotte site on that particular Saturday were flabbergasted to say the least. My lazy employer failed to mention to us they were spraying the building that day for COVID. My manager asked me for a picture of the gentleman in the hazmat suit, I took the photo on my cellphone sent it to my boss. He told us to leave immediately and that we would be compensated for a full day of work. Later my boss calls my personal cell on my time to tell me the photos I have taken were illegally obtained, since I took the photos on private property. He asked me to delete the photos and call any of my family members I sent them to, so they could also delete them from their phones. Unbelievable, right? 

Anyway don’t work for this company, anyone who currently works there in the ICC contact centers will be in my prayers. Perhaps, all departments aren’t bad, I just speak for the ICC contact centers AKA call center.

job_title: Home Loan Processor in Des Moines, IA
pros: Salary, flexibility. My manager is nice, but he doesn’t really know anything either, not faulting him here.
cons:
I’ve worked here in the department for less than 10 months. My department has been transitioned to 2 other departments since starting. This means I’ve had 3 roles since I started, which is incredibly unorthodox I believe, but I do understand Covid made somethings different. It wouldn’t be a big deal except every time I’ve been “trained” for my roles with WF, there has been almost ZERO training.  Even my manager doesn’t get trained or seem to know things. The job itself is fine, but talk about stress when you’re asked to do a job after literally 1-2 hrs of training and thrown new customers every day. I was in a call with my bosses, bosses, boss and when a question was presented with concerns about the constant transitions, they were told “HLP’s are here to execute leaderships goals, that’s the end of it.” After hearing that response, I’ve never, ever felt so much like a number and my opinion as employee is not cared for. I definitely have learned that if you work at Wells Fargo you do not get to express ANY concerns and if you do management makes you feel like you’re in the wrong for bringing it up. 

When it comes to the work itself, not anyone else seems to care about helping the customers than The HLP and HMC, who are bound to the underwriters schedule to look at anything. Customers are always disappointed in WF lack of concern on purchases/refinances. 

Also, there isn’t really any additional benefit given to employees who get Covid other than STD. Many other companies allowed you to take time off or made schedule adjustments for those with children related to Covid issues, but  not WF.
